div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was unplesantly warm until after sunset, when a deliciously cool easterly breeze sprung up and continued til nearly midnight. Then the wind chnaged to W. and the night was boisterous. The morning is dull, with light gales blowing, and the prospects are for more wind during the day. The barometer is falling.

div.p: The Egyptian Gazette
We áre again threatened With a rerious

months ago, it will be remembered, tha wear ers, after long negotiations, wait conceded an adtaice in wages of 7|%, end as ana total »corollary of their success the card-room operatives are now demanding an increase of 6%.' Ihe Utter have emphasised their determination to force the bands oi the employer* by delivering one month's notice to cease vrotk if their claims are not met It is stated by those who are wall able to give an opinion that
»a the rise is conceded there will inevitably a* strike at the beginning of May.

These frequent dispute! are mnoh to be deplored, not only from the point of view of the personal interests ot masters and Man, bat also, became of the serious menace to the trade of the County Paletiue and, incidentally, tbs: contrary generally that Is involved. There is much to be said for the position taken op by. the operatives. During the past eighteen months the oottpn industry has enjoyed' ancx ampled prosperity, and fheuoesanel profits have bean realised by owners of mills It therefore, to be expected that the workpeople should desife to share some of the benefit* of the boom. The reasonable as of this is admitted, hot it is unfortunate that it should seem to be neoessary, to order that justiod may be done, to resort to the old and very unsatii factory medium of a strike, a medium which, in the past, has wrought great havoc to all
engaged in the industry as well as to thousands who are affected by its prosperity or its slackness.

It is true that there is now to be observed a more common-sense view of the relations be tween mastora and man that has hitherto been absent, and the dispute last autumn led the offioUls to consider the advisability of adopting some system by which wages could bo automatically fixed. concerned) may be speedily aocumt iumed. We would suggest that the present seems a gooff opportunity to complet this, so that we may be spared the anxiety of another deadlock next month, The cotton industry is still exceesdingly presperets», and there is nothing to be gained, but a very great. deal to be lost by arbitrary conduct «either »ide, and the sanctioningg at this juncture notare of a sliding scale of wages would save us years

A fatal case of plague is reported from Tanah to day.

The last men's service will be held tomorow at 12.15 p.m.

We understand that the prospectus of this company will be published very shortly.
Egyptians at Milan.
A large number of natives, skilled in Egyp tian art, have applied to the Caire Gouvernorat for passports to Italy, where they intend to proceed to exhibit their handicraft in the Milan exhibition."
The "Hohenzollern".

The delayed cargo of the North German Lloyd 8. 8. Hohenzollern will arrivé at Alexandria from Genoa on the 12th inst. The goods will have to pay twenty five per cent. of their value on the general average fund.
Jeunes Economes des Pauvres.

We are asked by Mille Claire Ricard, presi deut of the Bavre des Jeanes Economes des Pauvres, to thank all who contributed to the success of the entertainment given in aid of the charity, more particularly the organiser of the fête, M. Christáki, as well as Maestró Marini and M. Moares.
Illusionists.

Door Leblanc, the well known illusionists, will give a performance at the New Khedivial Hotel to-morrow evening, previous toleaving for France on Friday. These artistes have met with great success in Cairo daring the past three months, giving exhibitions of their skill in the various saloons of the Capital. On Friday last they had the honour of appearing before H. H. the Khedive at Koubbeh Palace.
A Pervert

Hanna Girgis, a Cop: living in the Ghizeh Moddirieh, recently took it into his head that he would like to embrace the Moslem faith and notified the moudirieh authorities of his intention. The latter, as is the custom, called in two Coptic priests to try and dissuade him, from changing his religion, but to no purpose. Hanna Girgis was resolute and, having taken. the usual caths, has become a follower of Mohamed, who will henceforth be known as Mohamed Said.
Anglo-Belgian Co. of Egypt.

The only issue last month in London of a purely financial character was that of the Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt: As to other issues seven commercial enterprises were launched in the course.of the month, against fifteen in February, and of the seven three were rai ber companies. As many as twenty- Bix existing concerns appealed for new capital, the Grand Trunk figuring for a round million. Four mining companies made their bow, and, with one exception, were for small amounts. The total sum involved in March was 81 mil lions, whereas in February the amount ran to nearly 15 millions. Since the beginning of the year the new issues in London have totalled 274-millions sterling, as compared with 77 millions for the first quarter of 1995..
Attack by Madman..

"Ee Progrès" reports a disagreeable incident which occurred at Darb el Ahmar last Friday. Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, Lady Victoria Machell, and Captain Gordon Camming had been visiting the Ibrahim Agha M seque and had hardly take their seats in their carriage when a sheikh, who was standing at the door of the mosque, threw himself on Captain Camming and dealt him two blows on the head. Mr. Mackel who was sitting on the flap seat, jumped out the carriage and, after having warded off blow which the man aimed at him, succeded in overpowering the sheikh with the aid of his orderly and coachman. The man was taken to the caracol, where he was recognised as a hashish smoker who had already been confined in Abbassieh Asylum. He is again an inmate. of that institution. Captain Gordon Camming's injuries, though not dangerous, are sufficiently
severe.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H. H. the Khedive will return to Cairo from Alexandria on the 6th prox. to preside over the religious ceremony that attends the first night of the Mouled El-Nebi.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS OASIS.
div.p: Fifty lots of land were sold by the Cairo Electrio Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company on Saturday last, the prices ranging from P.T. 55 to P.T. 112 per sq metre. As the company bought the land from the Government at the low figure of L.E. 1 per feddan, it will gain enormously by the sale.

div.head: THE NEW CAIRO BOURSE.
div.p: The committee of the Corporation des Agente de Change, at its meeting held in Cairo yesterday, finally decided upon erecting the new Bourse Kbédiviale on the site re cently purchased from the Société Immobilière tor £30 000, and which forms part of the property formerly belonging to the late Sabit Pacha next to the Savoy Hotel. The site consists of about 2,800 square metres and is situated at the corner of the two new roads that are to cross the property in question at almost right angles.

The building, which is estimated to cost £35,000, will be a very handsome one. It is intended to have several offices on the ground floor, and these have already all been applied for by the leading brokers of the city. All the architects in the country have been invited to compete and the committee will accord two prizes of £250 and £100 res peetively, for the two best designs sent in, and these must reach them before the 5th Jane next.

We congratulate the committee upon the decision arrived at, which, in the opinion of almost everybody in the Capital, is considered by far the best and much superior to the original project sabmitted to them of building the new Bourse where the Hammam is now situated in Halim square....

div.head: CAIRO POST OFFICE.
div.p: The staff of postmen for the Cairo district has been increased by 31 men, which will enable the local postal authorities to increa in future the number of town deliveries from three to five daily, and suburban deliveries to three.

The branch, post office at Bab el-Khalk, near the Gouvernorat, will be opened to the public on the 20th instant. Several other branches are in contemplation, including one for the important district of Kasr el-Nil and Ismailis, and these will-be jopened as soon as the necessary credits have been obtained:

The number of private letter-boxes, lately increased to 1,100, has already been found insufficient, and a new applications are being daily received it has been decided to add another 400 such boxes at the central office.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: M: CHARLES BATTENBERG..

We deeply regret to report the death of M Charles Battenberg, judge assessor to the French Consulate and the Mixed Tribunal and Commercial Adviser to the French Go vernment, M. Battenberg: once was a man o business and an artist, in the wider sense o the term. An appreciation of what was nobles and best in art, a deep affection for literature and a sound critical taste make one regre that he was able to. devote so little time t verse, for which he had a genuine gift. Hi cattered poems deserve to be collected an plished-fow had read, them and know author, but those who had read with discernment realised that their author had trie poetic gift.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: QUESTION, IN PARLIAMENT.
NO NEED OF ARBITRATION.

In the House of Commons, last Monday, Mr. Bennett asked whether, in view of the sympathy so often: expressed by members of the present Government for the principle of arbitration in international disputes, they would offer to submit to arbitration the question whether or not Tabah was an integral portion of Egyp tian territory.

Mr. Ranciman said the Government had no reason to suppose that the question, at issue in regard to Tabah would not be settled by negotiation in the ordinary way, and that it would not be necessary to adopt any other
course.

div.head: THE RED SEA LINE..
div.p: That the Red Sea Railway was built in the shortest time possible is conceded by all who' know anything about the nature of work in this country But that it was wise to open it to traffic this year does not seem to be so, generally admitted. The rolling stock at the disposal of the tailway department was barely sufficient for the Halfs line, but now it has to be divided up between three lines. The dis location of business caused by the sudden change and the 'insufficiency of the rolling stock has been enormous. The same story comes from Halfa, Port Sudan, and Saakin. In. Khartoum merchants are patiently waiting for the time when the Red Sea line will be well equipped to meet the requirements of the country. In the meantime goods are accumulat ing at the port of entry and at Halts, and whereas it formerly took one month for goods to come from Egypt via Halfa, six weeks is now called prompt whichever way they come. ("Sadan Times").

div.head: SUDAN NOTES.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT). El Obeid, March 25. Since my last notes the Mondir (Miralai O'Connell Bey) and one or two other officers have come in from their patrols in 8. Kordofan. They experienced some heavy showers of rain and the natives all say that we shall have a very early and heavy kharif this year.
The Director of Woods and Forests, Mr. Brown, and Mrs. Brown paid us a visit the other day, and left for Khartoum via Bara few days ago.
There are remours aflost of surveyor for the railway between Omdurman and here having started work.
We are laying out a new polo ground about 1 miles oat from the Mondirish, and it promises to be an excellent ground and very fast.

div.head: SUDAN MINES' OPERATIONS.
div.p: The following is an extract from Mr.Griffin's cables, dated March 31 and April 2: "Gabait No. 1 Shaft-Have strack a body of rich ore in cross-cat dipping at an angle of 40 degrees. Estimated value 16 dwt. per ton for stoping width of 3 ft. at intersection; 3,000 gallons of water per 24 hours."

div.head: LORD KITCHENER AS GARDENER
div.p: The holding of a flower-show in Calcutta has had the effect of revealing Lord Kitchener in a new and attractive light (writes a correspondent). It now appears that there is a sentimental side to the character of the grim "K," as he is called in India. "K." is an enthusiastic gardener, and his delight is not In vegetables, as might have been expected, bat in flowers. Nor is he the kind of enthusiast who employs others to do the hard work. Het thinks nothing of doffing his coat to pile up a rockery and he is proud of his own skill. At the flower-show he won a cap by an exhibit of dendrobiums, a flower which, it has been suggested, won his favour by its Gregory powder aroma. The collection was grown and arranged by the Commander-in-Chief himself, who resented a slight change made by the show authorities.

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO.
div.p: MISS MARY HALL'S EXPERIENCES.
INTERESTING INTERVIEW.
Miss Mary Hall, whose journey across Atrica, was recently mentioned in our columns, has just arrived in London, and has been relating her experiences.
Miss Hall started her tour at Chinde, on the coast of Portuguese East Africa in June last. and reached Cairo about seven weeks ago. She had previously journeyed from the Cape to Victoria Falls.
During the whole of this nine months' journey she had a guard of only thirty negroes, which, considering the innumerable dangers to the traveller in unexplored Africa, was not strong one.

Except for my thirty bearers and porters, and my personal boy, I travelled alone," she said in the interview. For weeks at a time I saw no whites, and for weeks more had to subsist on jam, rice, cor flower, porridge, and cocos, I travelled where no white women, and only two white men, have,trod.

"I was carried in a hammock by reliefs of four, and for several weeks journeyed up rivers in a rowing boat, camping out on the banks at night. Often, on pitching camp, I have heard lions and hippopotami all around me, and have made my men form a complete circle of blazing fires round my tent. Sometimes I was frightened, for I knew that a rhino, if he chose, could crush me and my tent with one stroke of his forefoot,
"Lions, too, used to roar in the forest near me. I knew, however, that my men, for their own sakes, would keep up the fires, and I very Boon got used to it.

"My most exciting time was on the borders of German. South-West Africa: I could not for several weeks get permission to continue my journey, for there had been a vision of the natives, Finally I was allowed to proceed with a guard of two soldiers.

These soldiers as nearly as possible caused an attack by the natives. They wanted two of them to show us the way to the next river, and instead of asking if they could have them they carried off two by force. We had not gone far when I was told that several hundred of the tribe were pursuing us. They poured over the side of a hill just behind us, yelling their battle cries and brandishing their spears.

"I gave orders for a halt to be made, got out of my hammock, and faced them. On they came, but when a few yards off hesitated. I at once went forward, asked for the chief, and when he appeared I motioned the rest back. I was considerably disturbed when I found that we had carried off two of the tribe's principal men, but I explained that it was not done with my permission, and eventually managed to smooth things over." Miss Hall has many other adventures to tell. The very opposite of the popular idea of pioneer, she is a medium-sized lady with an open face and mild grey eyes. But there. is a firmness of mouth and chin, and a wideness of brow which is very significant.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: CHARGE OF ASSAULT.

Yesterday, Spiro Ellal, a Maltese and British subject, was brought before H.B.M.'s- Cons lar Court, Cairo, charged with stabbing one Raffaele Grech Cumbo on March 31. Mr. Alban, H.B.M.'s Consul, pre ided over the proceedings. The evidence of Mr. Fests, by whom the victim had been employed, was to the effect that the accused had been employed by Combo to do painting work... Witness had employed Cumbo. recently.

Dr. Walter Innes Bey described the affair, which he witnessed from a verandah near the corner where Safa-street joins the Sharia Madabegh. The accused and a man in a straw. hat, who were talking, came to words, and the latter finally struck accused, who threw himself on him. The two fell, the accused uppermost, and witness was surprised to hear loud shrieks from Arab women, not realising himself that anything serious had occurred. The Bocused rose and moved away, and witness them saw that he carried a knife which resembled that produced in Court. The wounded man turned and attempted to pursue Ellal, who then made off. Cumbo was much put about the face when witness came down to see him, his eye brows and forehead were gashed, and he was covered with blood. A kn fa thrust in the left side had passed between two ribs and must have been dangerously near the heart. The wounded man was taken to the Victoria Nurs ing Home and admitted on its being known. that Mr. Fests had employed him...

Mr. J. S Coronel, on being sworn, déposed that while driving up to Safa street he raw a orowd of people shouting and rushing about. He drove up and saw accused making off towards Messra Garrozo's works. He did not witness the encounter but saw the wounded man. His description of the injuries Cambo had sustained tallied with that given by Innes Bay. He desoribed the capture of accused by an arbagi and added that the natives struck him while he was held. He remonstrated with them, and stopped them. Acoused's knife was identified by him and he gave an account of the first aid. measures that were taken and of Cumbo's removal to the Victoria Nursing Home, The shawish who took Blul into custody and the arbagi who captured him were also examined, their evidence confirming that' already given in several details.
The case was adjourned till Tuesday next,

div.head: TAPOSIRIS MAGNA.
div.p: A LITTLE KNOWN RUIN.
INTERESTING TRIP TO ANCIENT CITY.

Few spots in the neighbourhood of Alexandria are as interesting and as little known as the extensive remains of the ancient city of Taposiris Magna, the old capital of Marmarica, and the committee of the Alexandria Archae ological Society are to be congratulated on having inaugurated their series of excursions yesterday by a visit to this site. A party of about fifty persons met yesterday morning at 8.45 o'clock at Wardian station, where a special train was in waiting which had been placed at the disposal of the society by the Dairs Khassa, Among those present were Mr. Gould, H. B. M.'s Consul General for the City and Port of Alexandria, and Mrs, and the Misses Gould, Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, Director General of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, Judge Haidallah Pacha, of the Mixed Court of Appeal, Baron von Bis sing, the well-known German archaeologist of Manich, Mr. Ambroise Ralli, President of the Alexandria Arcbæological Society, and Miss Ralli, Professor Freccia, Conservator of the Alexandria Museum, and Mrs. Breccia, Simond Bey and Mrs. Simond, Mr. and Mrs. Crafton, Dr. and Mrs. Osborne, Dr. Kanzki, Norsa Bey and Miss Norsa, Mr. Bindernagel, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Rothacker, Mr. Schuler, and many others.

The train lett Wardian at 9 o'clock and after a pleasant journey of about an hour through Mariont arrived at Beheig, where camels, horses and asses were in waiting to convey the party to their goal. An unfortun ate sccident occurred here to one of Mr. Gould's nieces, who was thrown from her camel, and fainted. Her injuries were such that Mr. and Mrs. Gould had to take her back at once to Alexandria. We hear this morning that no hones were broken but the young lady is severely bruised. The ride Boross the breezy Mariout op'anda to the rising ground on which Taposiris stands was & pleasant journey and the destination was soon reached. After climbing about the great. temple lanch was served, and afterwards Pro fessor Breccia gave the following account of the ancient city::

A l'appui, des auteurs classiques Pline: Strabon, Ptolémée, Dioscoride, Procope, Sté phane de Byzance qui nons ont laissé quelques renseignements sur la ville de Taposiris Magna, le Dr. Breccia démontre qu'il n'y a aucun doute pour l'identification des ruines que nous avons visitées. Ces raines sont bien celles de Taposiris Magos, comme d'ailleurs les voya geurs Pacho, Minutoli, Robecchi, Brichetti et le savant Mahmoud El-Falaki avaient déjà reconnu. Le Dr. Breccia & même rappele qu'en 1902, Mr. Pachandski, le géologue bien conna de notre ville, avait signalé l'endroit à l'attention de l'Institut Egyptien comme digne d'être exploré et qu'après lui l'archéologue Sokiff accompagné de notre concitoyen, Carl Herold, avait pas é oing jours sur les lieux pour copier les inscriptions. peintes qu'on avait observéesdans un tombeau à coupole à demi déblayé. Anjourd'hui, ajoute le Dr. Breccia, d'autres.ins criptions assez modernes, dont les auteurs méritent qu'on leur décerne un diplome de. stupidité viennent augmenter les anciennes, et il recommande à ses amis les excursionistes de ne pas se rendre dignes de ce diplome, Tout de suite après m'être orienté sur les travaux les plus urgents que j'avais A accomplir à Alexandrie, j'ai porté mon attention sur. Taposiris Magna et proposé & M. le Directeur Général, le professeur Maspero, un projet pour l'exploration superficielle du Mariont et pour des fouilles systématiques faire dans la Ville mentionnée plus haut. J'ai fait cela non seulement dans un bat seientifique, mais encore pour tacher de créer à Alexandrie et dans ses environs les curiosités indispensables à retenir les touristes, parce que je pense qu'on devrait commencer à renvoyer aux archivés la légende qu'à Alexandrie il n'y a rien à voir, légende que, comme toutes les maldicenze, tont le monde répète sans se donner la peine de la controler. Mr. Breccia remercie au nom de la Société et de la Ville le profesrear Maspero, qui a bien voulu approuver mon projet et mettre & ma disposition la somme nécessaire. Nos fouilles ont été les premières initiées sa Mariout qui d'ailleurs commence à devenir l'objet de l'attention des archéologues. En effet, le Révérend Kaufmann a entrepris il y a plusieurs mois de grandes fouilles à Karm. Abum, à une trentaine de kilomètres à l'inté rieur en face d'Aboussir, fouilles ont donné de splendides résultats. Nous avons raison de oroire que M. Kaufmann va inviter blentôt la Société visiter ses trouvailles. Les fouilles de Taposiris qui jaqa'ioi ont ooûté moins de trois mille fraños ont mis à jour une partie de la ville, c'est-à-dire des maisons en admirable état de conservation aveo toutes leurs annexes, des chapelles do mestiques, un, vaste système de canalisation des routes, aré néoropole d'oiseaux momifiés, des tombeaux à coupole, à puits, à. chambres. Parmi les objets il faut signaler des insorip tions, quelques soulptures, quelques statuettes en terre cuite, des marques en plâtre doré eto.. Aux ruines déjà découvertes, on ajouté la vae magnifique du grand temple, de la tour du ignal et celle incomparable de la mor et du paysage. On pourra no convaincre que l'exonr sión d'Abousir est une excursion digne d'être Taite non seulement par les savants et par les touristes, mais même par les Alexandrina qui par opetro yont chercher des sensations: très loin de leur ville. D'ailleurs, l'amour pour les choses mortes qu'on voudrait faire revivra n'est pas comme celui des femmes, jaloux et égoïste. Il a le défaut contraire. Oelui qui en a été pris tâche de le faire partager par tout le monde, même par ceux qui voudraient le con: sidérer comme an demi fou. Vous n'êtes pas dans cette catégorie, mais en tout cas si l'ex- öursion ne vous a pas satisfait, n'en voulez pas aux antiquités ni moi non plus.

After this discourse, had been delivered the pressor con lucted the party to various interesting tombs, remains of houses, and other vestiges of the ancient city: Only recently have excavations been made hare by the professor and some important finds have resulted. Every thing tends to show that the city was once of considerable importance, and a very large area is covered with the vestiges of former habitations. The site is a very favourable one for a town. The soil is dry and the situation lofty, on a range of hills overlooking the sea, which on this part of the coast is of an extra- ordinarily brilliant light blue colour owing to the reflection from the limestone rocks beneath, Bemains of roads and canals have been dis covered in the neighbourhood, and in the town itself the recent excavations have led to considerable finds of mummied birds and fishes, etc.

After a peregrination round the ruins tea was partaken of and the party reached Wardian again at 7p.m. The organisation of the exour hion was perfect, and a great deal of trouble was neccesitated in catering for angha large party: in, so out of the way a spot. The arrangements were in the hands of Norsa Bey, Director, of the Receipts Department of the Alexandria Municipality, and he is to be heartily congratulated on his complete success in the arduous task entrusted to him.

Bimbashi Stagni, of the Coastgaard Service, the Commandant of Shefa Khana Fort, who happened to be at Bebeig station buying horses when the accident occurred to Miss Gould, was unremitting in his attentions and was warmly thanked by the president of the society for his services.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Meath have returned to Alexandria and are staying again at Beau Rivage Hotel at Ramleh.
Rear Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blom: field have gone to Mera House Hotel to-day for a fortnight's stay.
Mr. A. L. Webb, C.M G., has left for England on three months' leave..
Lord Bdward Cecil has also gone on leave.
Mr. Ballard and Lady Maple, who were recently married at Nice, arrived to-day by the French steamer, and will spend part of. their honeymoon at Mana
The Hon. T. 4. and Lady Idina Brassey, on arriving last week at Naples from Alex andria, proceeded to Rome.

Sir Reginald Oaken, the general manager of the new Cairo Electric Railway, and Heliopolia Oasis Company lives. at Brussels and is the fourth Baronet of a creation of 1815. He was born in 1948 and succeeded to the title. in 1850. In 1982 he married Florence, dangh ter of M. Charles de Bela Broun lie, Vice- Consul at Parin.
Captain T. C. Bayley who has terminated his appointment as Staff Captain, in Egypt, embarked for England yesterday on the P. & O. steamer Persia

Lient TC. Onnningham, Inspecting Ordnanos Officer in Egypt, has been granted four months' sick leave on the recommendation of a medical board. He left Cairo yesterday for Port Said and embarked there in the P. & 0. 8.8. Persia for passage home.
Mr. and Mes. Montagu Summers are expected at the Bean-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh, to day.

Parker, Dr. Fele, Dr. Daniel, Mr. and Mrs. Whitfield, the Misses Portor, eto.

I am sorry, anya a London correspondent, to hear that Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, who has been in London of late, has been far from well. As one of those who offered imprisonment in their: enthusiasm for Ireland, he should live to see reality of better days for her. He must have ejoyed seeing the Liberal wave sweep the big, busy towns of England at the last election-a double pleasure to him; for, keen Radical that he has always been, he has been throughout his life lover of the oitos of men and their manifest activities, more perhaps than would generally be thought.by those who have known of him chiefly from his interest in Bgypt and Arab horses, an interest which speaks rather of deserts than of orowded streets.

REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

fractions of shares will be issued. Shares con-

not apply.
The shares now offered are payable as
follows :—
5/- per share on acceptance,
5/- per share on 24 th April next,
the balance by four equal instalments, when
reqoired, at intervals of not less than
three months and on one month's notice
being previously given.

Dear Sir or Madam,
In view of the satisfactory expansion that
has taken place in this Company's business in
Egypt, yoar Directors have decided to offer
146,940 shares for subscription pro rata to the
Shareholders as at 24th March, 1906, being at
the rate of one new share for every two shares
now held, at the price of £1 10.0 per share.
New shares will rank for dividend pari passu
with existing shares. No fractions can be
issued.
Yoar Directors are also glad to inform you
that an arrangement has been completed, by
which this issue has been guaranteed by
Messrs. Ochs Brothers and Messrs. Reid and
Barnard of Cairo and Alexandria, in considera-
tion of a commission of 2/6 per ihare and the
right to acquire at the price named, any shares

5/-per share on acceptance,
